reasoning: The query expresses concern about South Africa annexing Lesotho, citing economic and social burdens on South Africa.  It highlights existing problems in South Africa like poverty and inequality, arguing that these should be addressed before taking on additional responsibilities. The analysis aims to identify terms that capture the core concerns:  economic hardship, social inequality, and the potential negative consequences of annexation for South Africa.
query_goals: understand the economic implications of annexing Lesotho
analyze the social impact of annexation on South Africa
evaluate the potential costs and benefits of annexation
augmented_query: South Africa Lesotho annexation economic burden poverty inequality resources stability social problems  international relations regional integration
query: It is not in the interest of South Africa to annex a poor, underdeveloped country  It is not in South Africa’s interests to annex Lesotho. Lesotho would be a burden; it is poor, might cause instability, and has no resources as compensation. On a simple cost-benefit analysis made by the SA government they would clearly see they would have more responsibility towards the Basotho population but new resources to fulfil those responsibilities. South Africa has its own problems that it should be focusing on first. Poverty is officially at 52.3% [1] and unemployment is a great problem for South Africans; a quarter of the majority black workforce is unemployed. [2] Moreover, Only 40.2% of black infants live in a home with a flush toilet, a convenience enjoyed by almost all their white and Indian counterparts showing the inequality that still exists in the ‘rainbow nation’. [3] Why add more people under your protection when you can’t take care of your own?  [1] ‘Statement by Minister in The Presidency for Performance Monitoring and Evaluation, Collins Chabane, on the occasion of the launch of the Development Indicators 2012 Report’, thepresidency.gov.za, 20 August 2013,   [2] Mcgroarty, Patrick, ‘Poverty Still Plagues South Africa's Black Majority’, The Wall Street Journal, 8 December 2013,   [3] Kielburger, Craig & Marc, ‘Why South Africa is Still Dealing With Segregation and Poverty’, Huffington Post, 18 December 2013,
cleaned_augmented_query: south africa lesotho annexation economic burden poverty inequality resources stability social problems international relations regional integration
initial_results:
### Text snippet from document at k=1
: It is not in the interest of South Africa to annex a poor, underdeveloped country  It is not in South Africa’s interests to annex Lesotho. Lesotho would be a burden; it is poor, might cause instability, and has no resources as compensation. On a simple cost-benefit analysis made by the SA government they would clearly see they would have more responsibility towards the Basotho population but new resources to fulfil those responsibilities. South Africa has its own problems that it should be focusing on first. Poverty is officially at 52.3% [1] and unemployment is a great problem for South Africans; a quarter of the majority black workforce is unemployed. [2] Moreover, Only 40.2% of black infants live in a home with a flush toilet, a convenience enjoyed by almost all their white and Indian counterparts showing the inequality that still exists in the ‘rainbow nation’. [3] Why add more people under your protection when you can’t take care of your own?  [1] ‘Statement by Minister in The Presidency for Performance Monitoring and Evaluation, Collins Chabane, on the occasion of the launch of the Development Indicators 2012 Report’, thepresidency.gov.za, 20 August 2013,   [2] Mcgroarty, Patrick, ‘Poverty Still Plagues South Africa's Black Majority’, The Wall Street Journal, 8 December 2013,   [3] Kielburger, Craig & Marc, ‘Why South Africa is Still Dealing With Segregation and Poverty’, Huffington Post, 18 December 2013,

### Text snippet from document at k=2
: The population in Lesotho might be suffering from poverty but this is not their fault but rather the result of the bad governance. Lesotho is investing 12% of its GDP in education and 85% of its population over 15 is literate. [1] This can provide an knowledgeable, smart workforce for SA which can help develop both countries. On the other hand, South Africa is also dependent on one resource from Lesotho and this is water. Over the past 25 years, a mutual, bilateral agreement has been made between the two sovereign states so that the Lesotho Highlands Water Project can provide SA with clean water. [2] Moreover, the textile industry in Lesotho is competitive and profitable. The industry still contributes close to 20 percent of Lesotho's annual gross domestic product, and is its largest employer. [3] Lesotho would clearly not just be a burden.  [1] The World Factbook, 2014,   [2] Ashton, Glenn, ‘A Case for Closer Integration between South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland?’, The South African Civil Society Information Service,   [3] ‘LESOTHO: Textile industry gets a lifeline’, IRIN, 24 November 2011,

### Text snippet from document at k=10
: Countries on the UNSC do already take an interest in the Africa, illustrated by French troops helping local democratic governments form Mali and CAR defeat various outlaw rebel groups. [1]  Secondly, simply giving a veto to an Africa nation, does not guarantee that they will promote beneficial policies. South Africa for example has been accused of using UNSC membership to defend human rights abusers, South Africa’s response was that human rights "have always targeted mainly the developing countries". [2]  [1] “Sand on their boots”, The Economist, Jan 24th 2013   [2] Humphreys, Joe, ‘SA defends human rights voting at UN’, The Irish Times, 20 November 2007,
thought_process:
As I delve into the query about South Africa annexing Lesotho, my initial impression is that this is a complex issue involving political, economic, and social considerations. The query itself highlights the potential burdens Lesotho might impose on South Africa, including economic hardship, instability, and the lack of resources. However, it also underscores South Africa's own internal issues, such as poverty and inequality, which might be exacerbated by such an annexation. This makes me think about the broader implications of annexation, not just for South Africa and Lesotho, but also for the region and potentially the global community.

Analyzing the results of the original query, I notice that the top-ranked documents emphasize the economic and social challenges that both countries face. There's a clear concern about the cost-benefit analysis of annexation, with some arguments suggesting that Lesotho could bring knowledgeable and smart workforce to South Africa, potentially benefiting both countries. However, other perspectives point out the dependency on Lesotho's water resources and the competitive textile industry, which could be both a boon and a burden. This dichotomy tells me that the issue is multifaceted and requires a nuanced approach.

To systematically approach this query expansion, I decide to use the conceptual graph traversal technique. This involves identifying core concepts and entities in the original query, determining the search intent, and listing any implicit assumptions or constraints. The core concepts here are "South Africa," "Lesotho," "annexation," "economic burden," "poverty," "inequality," and "resources." The search intent appears to be informational, aiming to understand the implications of annexation. An implicit assumption might be that the economic and social welfare of both countries would be significantly impacted.

Constructing a conceptual graph, I start with these core nodes and then expand to first-order connections, such as the economic dependencies between the two countries, the social implications of annexation, and the political context of regional integration. Second-order connections might include related concepts like development aid, economic dependency, and the role of international organizations. Domain contexts could involve fields like economics, political science, and international relations.

For expansion path selection, I identify several promising directions: synonymous terms for economic burden and poverty, hierarchical terms related to regional integration and international relations, compositional terms such as specific industries or resources, and contextual terms related to the historical and political context of South Africa and Lesotho. Domain-specific terminology could include concepts from development economics and political science.

As I traverse the conceptual graph and extract terms, I filter them based on relevance, distinctiveness, specificity, and searchability. This process involves some trial and error, reconsidering initial assumptions, and making intuitive connections between seemingly disparate concepts. For instance, the concept of "water resources" leads me to think about environmental sustainability and the potential for cooperative management of shared resources, which in turn suggests terms like "transboundary water management" and "environmental cooperation."

Through this systematic yet flexible approach, I start to see insights emerge that complement the original query. Terms like "economic integration," "regional development," "social cohesion," and "political stability" become apparent as crucial for understanding the annexation's implications. The technique helps to uncover these terms systematically, but it's the natural thought process—considering tangents, making connections, and occasionally reconsidering initial paths—that adds depth and nuance to the query expansion.

Ultimately, synthesizing these insights with clarity, I believe the expanded query should capture both the explicit and implicit aspects of the original query. This involves selecting terms that not only reflect the core concepts but also the broader contextual and domain-specific considerations. The final expanded query should thus include terms that encapsulate the economic, social, political, and environmental dimensions of the potential annexation of Lesotho by South Africa.
